events.originalText: American acrobat Nik Wallenda became the first person to walk a tightrope stretched directly over Niagara Falls.
events.subtitle: Nik Wallenda
events.headline: Nik Wallenda walks tightrope over Niagara Falls

events.originalText: US president George W. Bush designated 140,000 square miles (360,000 km2) around the Northwestern Hawaiian Islands as the Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument, now one of the world's largest protected areas.
events.subtitle: George W. Bush
events.headline: George W. Bush designates Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument

events.originalText: Leaders of China, Russia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan formed the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation.
events.subtitle: Shanghai Cooperation Organisation
events.headline: Shanghai Cooperation Organisation formed by China, Russia, and others

events.originalText: The Troubles: The Provisional Irish Republican Army detonated a truck bomb in the commercial centre of Manchester, England, injuring more than 200 people and causing widespread damage to buildings.
events.subtitle: The Troubles
events.headline: IRA detonates truck bomb in Manchester, England

events.originalText: Western Greece was struck by an earthquake registering 6.4–6.5 Mw that killed 26 people.
events.subtitle: 1995 Aigio earthquake
events.headline: Earthquake in Western Greece kills 26

events.originalText: The eruption of Mount Pinatubo in the Philippines deposited large amounts of particulate matter into the atmosphere, enough to lower global temperatures by about 0.5 °C (0.9 °F).
events.subtitle: Mount Pinatubo
events.headline: Mount Pinatubo eruption lowers global temperatures

events.originalText: King Hussein of Jordan married American Lisa Halaby, who became known as Queen Noor of Jordan (pictured).
events.subtitle: Hussein of Jordan
events.headline: King Hussein of Jordan marries Lisa Halaby

events.originalText: In the Saskatchewan general election, the Co-operative Commonwealth Federation led by Tommy Douglas  won enough seats in the Legislative Assembly to form the first socialist government in North America.
events.subtitle: 1944 Saskatchewan general election
events.headline: Tommy Douglas leads CCF to victory in Saskatchewan election

events.originalText: World War II: The United States Army Air Forces began its first air raid on the Japanese home islands, although little damage was caused.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: US Army Air Forces launch first air raid on Japan

events.originalText: Bessie Coleman (pictured) became the first Black person to earn an international pilot's license from the Fédération Aéronautique Internationale.
events.subtitle: Bessie Coleman
events.headline: Bessie Coleman earns international pilot's license

events.originalText: Three African-American circus workers were lynched by a mob in Duluth, Minnesota, a crime that shocked the country for having taken place in the Northern United States.
events.subtitle: Duluth lynchings
events.headline: Three African-American circus workers lynched in Duluth

events.originalText: An earthquake registering 8.5 Mw and subsequent tsunami struck Japan, killing at least 22,000 people and destroying about 9,000 homes.
events.subtitle: 1896 Sanriku earthquake
events.headline: Earthquake and tsunami strike Japan, killing thousands

events.originalText: Eadweard Muybridge took a series of photographs to prove that all four feet of a horse leave the ground when it gallops, which became the basis of motion pictures.
events.subtitle: Eadweard Muybridge
events.headline: Eadweard Muybridge proves horse gallop in motion pictures

events.originalText: The shooting of a pig in the San Juan Islands led to the so-called Pig War over the border between the United States and British North America.
events.subtitle: San Juan Islands
events.headline: Pig War erupts over border dispute between US and British North America

events.originalText: War of the Second Coalition: France and Austria agreed the Convention of Alessandria, bringing a temporary peace between the two nations.
events.subtitle: War of the Second Coalition
events.headline: France and Austria agree Convention of Alessandria for temporary peace

events.originalText: Pope Leo X issued the papal bull Exsurge Domine, censuring 41 propositions from Martin Luther's Ninety-five Theses and subsequent writings, and threatening him with excommunication unless he recanted.
events.subtitle: Pope Leo X
events.headline: Pope Leo X censures Martin Luther with Exsurge Domine

events.originalText: King John of England and a group of rebel barons agreed on the text of Magna Carta, an influential charter of rights.
events.subtitle: John, King of England
events.headline: King John of England agrees on Magna Carta text

events.originalText: The Bur-Sagale eclipse was observed in Assyria, the earliest solar eclipse mentioned in historical sources that has been successfully identified.
events.subtitle: 760s BC
events.headline: Earliest solar eclipse in Assyria observed during Bur-Sagale
